bug.short_desc: [deployables] EAR members() doesn't return binary archive children

long_desc.thetext:
ProjectModule.members() doesn't return all children of a project. I have a jar in the EarContent folder of an EAR project. I call the members() of the EAR project, I don't the jar back. I only get the application.xml back.
My own ref number: 382034
Created an attachment (id=47714) Proposed patch

The problem for this defect is related to the change in WTP 1.5 where we added binary module support to EARs. The deployables were filtering out all archives when in fact they should only be filtering out j2ee binary modules. The fix also ensures we return the right children for getChildModules().
These binary changes also broke some web module libraries support. The external jars were also being filtered out.
To fully fix this and get a complete review, there is a new JUnit which tests all the scenarios for web and ear project interactions. I will attach this Junit, it is just being cleaned up right now.

FYI - I did make a protected method change to try and clean up the code. We had a getUtilMembers() method which always did all the work within it and never returns anything. So, I changed it to addUtilMembers() to clarify and to prevent the creation of extra objects and adds. This is a protected method in an internal class which is not extended.
Reviewing...just waiting for the JUnit.

bug.short_desc: Test Execution Model needs to include the case of no verdict in TPFExecutionResult.

long_desc.thetext: The current test execution result (TPFExecutionResult) in the test execution model contains an attribute for the overall test result verdict (TPFVerdict). TPFVerdict is an pre-defined enumeration currently includes: pass, fail, error and inconclusive. TPFExecutionResult always defaults to the inconclusive verdict even in the case of no verdict at all, which can not accuratly represent the real value of execution result.
Changed component to Platform.Model since this is a test model change.

Based on the conclusion for the 4.2.1 fix to the related defect 144045, looking ahead at future improvements in this area of overall test verdict arbitration(which was the original intent of Bianca filing this defect)Harm commented:
> I think we need to still look at the scenarios that create the "no verdicts" situation, assess the arbiter impl, and then go back to see if there are needs for extension points and the model itself in 4.3
I'm agreed on the last three points. Regarding the first, in general I don't think the situation of "missing verdicts" is a fault that needs to be corrected, but a condition that TPTP needs to handle. The idea of using the test log for purposes other than establishing an overall verdict should be perfectly legitimate. Our consuming product has a number of test log options that allows the user to tailor the test log for the particular purpose of a run such as debugging or workload validation, and a number of them don't produce verdicts. For example, in load testing you don't want to be inundated with millions of VPs that worked fine but you do want details when something doesn't work, and so we have a filtering option to only show failures, errors and/or warnings. With this option, if everything is successful the test log will have no verdicts.
If we determine that we want to proceed with the UI extension point in 4.3 or later, its design should leverage registration based on the test type which produced the specific test log. This would allow vendors to control behavior as appropriate for their test types without impacting others. Otherwise it will have the same shell sharing issue that #2 (command line option) had that Mike Norman previously called out, which is that when multiple TPTP-based products are installed into the same shell, perhaps by different vendors, that the behavior for one product may change based on the command line option applied by another product/vendor.

bug.short_desc: org.eclipse.draw2d.Animation has memory leak

long_desc.thetext:
It appears that Animation has a memory leak due to the static field "toCapture". This field is never nulled out. Several other fields are nulled in the cleanup() method, but toCapture is not. This has some serious consequences because "toCapture" holds objects referring to palette model in the collection. If the model objects hold onto large objects, the leak can be substantial.
The leak can be reproduced by opening an editor with a palette, causing any animation in the palette, and then closing the editor.

GEF team: the leak does not grow over time, otherwise it would be critical/blocker (in the absence of a workaround).
This should be targeted for the maintenance release.
Is this going to be fixed for 3.2.1, in a large product based on eclipse, we depend on this fix, to get rid of a memory leak from the palette.
Is there a workaround that components depending on the Animation, can themselves implement ?
Will this bug be fixed for 3.2.1? Please assign or defer. Thanks.

I had asked Randy about a potential workaround, and he said we might be able to perform an "empty" animation after the drawer was touched. He thought I should definitely work with the GMF team to find the best workaround though.
If I examined the code correctly, this bug just involves nulling out the field 'toCapture' in the 'cleanup()' method of the Animation class though. If that is true, I would think that this bug has a high ease-of-fix to benefit ratio.
creating a patch to fix the memory leak

Created an attachment (id=49991) patch to fix the memory leak
I have checked with Randy to make sure the fix make sense to him

Committed the patch to R32_Maintenance branch.
(I added a corrected copyright: 2005, 2006)

attachment.desc: patch to fix the memory leak

bug.short_desc: Please renormalise the IDE menu structure.

long_desc.thetext:
After discourse of Bugzilla #153141, I am jumping into a conclusion that Eclipse UI menu structure needs "renormalisation" (a term physicists and their mathematics relatives use).
For the past twenty years, I see the need and desire for orthogonality in a menu structure. However, my persuasion is that the need for human ease of use and comprehensiveness over-rides any and all of the UI developers' desires for menu and product-layer orthogonality.
e.g., defining variables is bizarre. It is so VAX/VMS-esque (in their so called "layered products") - which I find outmoded. How would I know "declaring variables" had anything to do with attaching libraries. Just be straight forward and declare library elements and the jars constituting them. We should be able to have a menu item which say "Manage Libraries" - a straight forward terminology.
The use of an intermediate intervention called "variables" helps in objectivising and layering to allow a technology to be constructed orthogonally.
However, IBM (and its derivative organisations) repeatedly forget that there are more than one frames of orthogonality in any software products. There is a concept called "humans" (if IBM has yet to realise). And humans have their own frames of orthogonality. When the frames of human and machine orthogonality clash, as they often do, the human frames should always be allowed to triumph.
Despite the staleness of stoking an ancient fire, I wish to remind the conflicts between O/S2 and MS Windows. Recall the time when IBM sales/marketing went around the world explaining that O/S2 had a real object oriented core while MS Win had only a pretentious one. I always chuckled behind the crowd because I realised that IBM had forgotten that real object orientation was of no significance to humans but a few. The frame of machine orthogonality IBM was promoting was not in harmony with the frames of orthogonality of various clans of humans.
Whilst MS Win allowed various UIs to see the file system, O/S2 allowed me only one. Increasingly third party MS Win desktops allowed us more choices.
On the other hand, Apple UI was successful because they found a niche clan of humans with widely similar set of orthogonality. Both MS and Apple successfully hid their machine orthogonality (or otherwise dis-orthogonality) from the user. On the contrary, IBM's products has frequently been to expose (or even boast about) the machine orthogonality.
Therefore, the trick is having a hidden machine orthogonality that would allow it to take on various guises - e.g. more than one navigator view - a highly configurable UI. Since there is not a common frame of human orthogonality, a few (about three would suffice) UI schemes should be preconfigured to satisfy the most common set of human frames.
I am realising that my post here is itself not too comprehensive while the term "orthogonality" may not be familiar with too many people and my stoking an ancient fire not too helpful. However, I hope there are enough people who understand the intention of my post and give us a nice and comfortable IDE to use.
Can you please elaborate what you mean by "renormalisation". A better menu structure? Can you give concrete examples what is bad and how you would change it?
Please read my comments/rants in 163100.

bug.short_desc: Wrong classpath for binary projects with linked content

long_desc.thetext:
During export, for binary projects with linked content, pde/ui provides us with a dev.properties map so that we can find the libraries.
However, when placing libraries on the classpath, the paths are treated as relative to the bundle. In the case of linked content, this results in an incorrect path: .../org.eclipse.osgi/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.osgi._3.2.100.v2006.jar
We should recognize when we have an absolute path for the library because of dev.properties and leave it as such, or do the proper work to make it relative instead of just appending it.
Note that during a headless build, we will not have the dev.properties and will be unable to located the linked library. Do we need to worry about this use case?

Brian put a patch to fix this on bug 158589

bug.short_desc: SaveScopeResourcesHandler.handleStatus doesnt handle return value from DebugUIPlugin.preLaunchSave()

long_desc.thetext:
When a user goes to launch something from Eclipse, it looks at all the dirty editors and prompts the user with "Do you want to save this file before launch?" The user gets Yes,No,Cancel buttons. The user presses Cancel and expects that means "Dont launch." Instead the launch continues like nothing happened.
Tracking through the code it seems like a 'false' is returned from DebugUIPlugin.preLaunchSave(), but SaveScopeResourcesHandler.handleStatus() doesnt seem to care. It returns true. Therefore, my LaunchConfigurationDelegate.preLaunchCheck() doesnt know that the user pressed Cancel so it cant take any action either. In my case, in our LaunchConfigurationDelegate.preLaunchCheck(), we call super.preLaunchCheck() and we monitor the return value.

DebugUIPlugin.preLaunchSave has been deprecated and in its place implementors are to use SaveScopedResourceHandler to perform saving and the like.
One of the reasons for deprocation was the 'yes, no, cancel' problem. With SaveScopedResourceHandler there is only 'ok, cancel' and clicking cancel kills the launch (as it should). The only place that the two are tied in is in SaveScopedResourceHandler, which if all else fails will fall back to the old prelaunch save.
The easiest way to take advantage of the this is to extend LaunchConfigurationDelegate.

OK, thanks. Ill look into that. The only thing I dont understand though is why isnt this all done under the covers for me if things are being deprecated? In other words, why do I have to extend LaunchConfigurationDelegate to take advantage of this? Seems like the platform ought to just take care of this for me. Just curious.

Thats a really good question, it was because we made the assumption that most implementors would extend LaunchConfigurationDelegate, as opposed to doing it themselves. For those that do not use LaunchConfigurationDelegate, that was the reason for the javadoc about a breaking change.
If you want to use SaveScopedResourceHandler without LaunchConfigurationDelegate, you can, as it is provided in the debug.core plugin. For an example of how to make use of it on your own see line 96 in LaunchConfigurationDelegate.
I will mark this bug as INVALID, if you have any more questions don't hesitate to email me.

bug.short_desc: Support for Page Sequences as described in Page Setup Spec

long_desc.thetext:
As of BIRT 2.1 page sequences as described in the Page Setup Specification document are still not supported.
There seems to be no way to use a different master page for the title page, when the Report body is just a simple list of records. In this case the multiple master page support is not applicable, because there is no element which can switch to another master page on from the second page of the report.
Please add support for page sequences to support the simple case of using one Master Page for the Title and some othe Master Page for following pages.

On the title page, do you want to show the report title only, or you want to show the title AND some rows in the simple list of records?
Do you have grouping on row no so that in HTML the simple listing will have page breaks?

(In reply to comment #1) > On the title page, do you want to show the report title only, or you want to > show the title AND some rows in the simple list of records? >
The title page shall contain rows of the simple list of records AND the some fields which shall be displayed below this records (in the footer section).
> Do you have grouping on row no so that in HTML the simple listing will have > page breaks? >
No, I have no grouping enabled at the moment.

I am thinking a solution that
1) create a group on the row_no with N # of rows 2) set page break on this group as always except first group. 3) in the onpageBreak() script for this group this.getStyle().masterPage = "Body";

(In reply to comment #4) > I am thinking a solution that
> 3) in the onpageBreak() script for this group > this.getStyle().masterPage = "Body";
Setting the masterPage property during onpageBreak() has no effect, at least for the PDF Emitter in Build N20060808.
My findings are, that it works in onCreate() only.

+1 to support two usages in onPageBreak() scripting:
(1) switch to a different pre-defined master page (2) change the contect/properties of a pre-defined master page.
add plan key word.

bug.short_desc: Request for -clean (osgi.clean) to clear all temporary data

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse -clean is a frequent resort for those of us on the bleeding edge, and should get us back to a reliable point from which we can follow a sequence of actions that lead to the appearance of a bug.
At the moment, this is not the case. There is a bug somewhere that is causing me significant headaches, and the only way out of it is to shut down eclipse and empty the contents of .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.jdt.core.
Surely eclipse -clean should be deleting temporary index files?
Move to Platform/Resources

The -clean argument only flushes the configuration state under eclipse/configuration. Contrary to popular belief it isn't a cure-all for arbitrary failures, and it has nothing to do with workspace state under the .metadata directory at all.
Having said that, if you have a error that is only solved by flushing the JDT index files, it suggests there is a problem there worth investigating. Moving back to JDT core for investigation. Any details you can provide would be useful - log file messages or other error messages, a description of the failure symptoms, what Eclipse build you are using, etc.

Hi,
The bug for which these files have to be cleared out seems to be in Webtools, and has been reported as bug #155322, so this bug could be closed.
In light of what you say about -clean, then I'll make this bug an enhancement request for a -flush (or something) option to request that plugins clear their temporary files would be useful. At the moment, I'm finding that attempting to support Eclipse by installing milestone and RC releases is made so much more painful because of issues like this.
Thanks,
neale
So, put back this enhancement to Platform/Resources as this is not specific to JDT/Core. (I apologize for the first bug triage which was made a little bit too quickly...)
Neale, can you double check that bug number? Bug 155322 doesn't seem to exist yet.
Sorry. Typo on that bug, which is bug #153322
*** Bug 154320 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I don't really like this idea. Throwing away all metadata because of undiagnosed problems just seems like the wrong approach, and having such a flag suggests that it's a normal work flow. Plugins should really be able to recover on their own if their metadata becomes corrupt; I know for example that the JDT core throws away indexes if there are errors reading them. However, I will move this to runtime for consideration - for arbitrary plugins to be able to flush their metadata such a feature could not exist in the resources plugin. My recommendation would be WONTFIX. (in any event users always have the option to start a new workspace and import settings and projects from the old workspace into the new)

Thanks John.
I note you say "I know for example that the JDT core throws away indexes if there are errors reading them." Shouldn't that mean that I should never have needed to manually flush those index files?
I'll take that issue up as the other bug, and the webtools/JDT teams can fight it out :)
I'm not sure about the suggestion of WONTFIX. As I see it, the -clean option is not a part of normal workflow either, as otherwise it might be a menu option (restart and clean).
My request is notably to have the facility exist that makes it much easier to recover from bugs while using early releases. Perhaps it might be counter-productive to code quality as people might not be so inclined to investigate further...
Your call :)

Apologies for the duplicate (bug 154320). Both are about flushing in part or whole plugin metadata, this one for a command line option to fix workspace problems, the duplicate for a UI option to better manage storage space.
My reason for filing the duplicate was that metadata directories can quickly grow to over 50MB, which is a lot of data the user may not know is in their workspace and soon eats up disk quota. Much of this is stale, e.g. history files, old local server deployments, log backups, caches etc. but it isn't clear what may safely be deleted. Managing this would seem to fit with the consumability theme.
The motivation for both bugs should be considered before deciding whether to WONTFIX.

Note that if you say -clean that sets the property osgi.clean. Bundles are free to look at that property at startup (whenever) and decide if they should toss cached state. -flush would just end up setting a different property for bundles to look at. It is not clear that we need to distinguish between the cases here.
As John pointed out, adding these kinds of sledge hammers is less than optimal. However, it may be reasonable during developement as we have bugs in caching algorithms etc.
i suggest that people open bugs against the individual bundles which are causing them trouble.
This bug should likely be closed as the solution lies elsewhere.

Closing as per comment 8 and comment 11.
If the problem with JDT metadata is reproducible, please open a bug for it; I would imagine that conditions under which it occurs along with offending metadata would be nice to have there.
I myself agree with John and Jeff. Two more points: - IMHO, runtime should not delete data from .metadata unless it knows what it is; - Nothing really prevents plugins from storing data elsewhere
From the practical side, this is really easy to work around with a two-line batch file - unless I am missing something?

Sorry, but a throwaway comment about a two line.bat file is not useful, when you consider how much time that I alone had to invest in order to find the workaround in the first place. A consistent approach to data that is built at startup is required across the whole platform.
Why should supportive bleeding-edge users have to write a .bat file... they already have to create a new startup link for the occasional -clean (which *could* be supported from within the UI).
I am re-opening, as request for the platform to require that osgi.clean is obeyed by all plugins for their temporary data.
This could as you request, be a specific to request to the JDT, but this is a valid platform wide issue that could be solved consistently.

Neale, I understand your frustruation but we are not in a position to force anyone to do anything. The other challenge here is that people doing as you suggest (and a reasonable suggestion it is) will get hit by others saying they should'nt do it. For example, assume that JDT clears their all types cache on -clean. Now someone uses -clean to address some configuration issue. When they have to wait for JDT to reindex their entire world they will file a bug report.
Dunno, perhaps I just argued myself out of my statement in comment 11...

Thanks Jeff.
I'll follow 11 through to the JDT team, as I think it does have merit. It does, however, seem a complete pain that we are left with "delete your workspace" as the alternative. I think if we weren't happy having an excuse to upgrade to the next quad core processor, then we'd probably only go with release versions :)
Cheers,
Neale
feel free to contribute a quad core processor or two to the Equinox team. Perhaps we could talk about adding -flush ;-)
Not planning to address this.

bug.short_desc: Dependent projects lost from Dynamic Web Project

long_desc.thetext:
I have a Dynamic Web Project (DWP) that uses 8 other java projects, in use via the Projects tab of Java Build Path.
Normally, these projects correctly deploy, listing the 8 projects in the tree under my DWP, when I select Run As->Run On Server, and click next. (server is Tomcat 5.5 in this instance)
Some time later, after many edit, build and re-publish cycles, perhaps including times when the automatic re-publish has failed when the server was running, I find that not everything is getting deployed to the server (in .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core).
So, I delete the server from the Servers view (thus cleaning out .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.wst.server.core) and re-create the server.
At this point, doing Run On Server, I don't get all of those child projects (perhaps explaining why things weren't working).
The following cycle, which I would have thought quite adequate, does not solve this problem: - Disable automatic build - Clean all projects - Remove all servers - Shut down - Relaunch eclipse using 'eclipse -clean'
After much tearing out of hair, I discovered a clue, in that clearing out .metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.jdt.core and then relaunching, solves the problem. [This, I would have expected eclipse -clean to do, and have reported seperately as bug #153321]
It seems something is going wrong and corrupting some element of the JDT indexer that is being relied upon by Webtools, but beyond that, I'm stuck.
Help..!
Sorry. Forgot to clarify that it is 1.5.0 / Callisto release

May now be possible for you to reproduce this one by reducing memory.

Hi Neale, I've recently fixed two problems in 1.5.1 that might be related: 1) servers keeping some metadata around after deletion, which caused new servers created with the same name to have incorrect state and not publish correctly. 2) clean build caused files to be removed from publish directory, and not always refreshed
It sounds like the only remaining issue is the JDT problem you were having and running out of memory. Are you still seeing this behaviour? Do you want me to transfer this to the platform JDT team?

Hi Tim,
I tracked down the PermGen crash, which is covered in bug 129490. As I think you got, that crash itself is not the issue, just a way of causing the general case of JDT failing to recover after a crash.
I'm not sure that your fixes address this issue, but if they are in the current build, then I'll update and drop my -XX:MaxPermSize=128m (one solution to the PermGen issue) back to the JDK default, or lower, and see if I can cause the bug, and verify that your changes have solved the problem.
I agree that the solution may be down to the JDT team, but I was wary that it might be something in WTP as the only symptom of the index file corruption is WTP specific (i.e. that some Web modules are lost from the dyn web project).
Must admit, I'm now getting quite a warm feeling about the 1.5.1 release... if only all those unassigned bugs in the JSP tagfile validation got actioned... I'd be over the moon.
Hope your weekend is as good as has been earned.
All the best,
Neale

Tim,
FYI, on bug 153321, John is saying that JDT automatically flushes the indexes if an error is detected reading them.
That has me puzzled as to how Eclipse is successfully reading them, when they have clearly lost some data...

Hi Neale,
Sorry for the delayed response. I've been looking at the related bugs, and it looks like most of the PermGen issues have been resolved or aren't reproducable on other Eclipse/JVM combinations. Have you had a chance to try 1.5.2 or a 1.5.3 build, and do you still see the problems? I'm not sure what I should be doing (or if there is anything I can do) with this bug.

Hi Tim,
If we've no one else reporting this, then I'd suggest we assume you got it, and close this but.
I've not seen it since, and I'm on 1.5.2. Having said that, I now run with a bigger PermGen allocation, so I've not crashed Eclipse in that way since.
Nice to see how things are shaping up for 2.0. The 'experimental tomcat 5.5 plugin" will be very welcome here, as well as the mention I've seen of possibly supporting web content in utility projects. Will be good to see what we get when features are stable.
Have a great 2007.
Regards,
Neale
Thanks, Neale.
Closing as fixed since WTP 1.5.2. Please reopen if closed in error.

bug.short_desc: better view of generic type information

long_desc.thetext:
I just cobbled the example together from a much more complicated situation that prompted my request. I thought I had captured the essence of the problem but evidently not. If nothing else, this gets to the heart of the matter in that the hovers in my situation show that the type resolves to Collection, not Set, and I could never get an adequate "picture" of what is going on with regard to type resolution.
Perhaps it would be helpful if the Outline view (or some more advanced view, such as a context sensitive "type" view) were able to show the resolved types instead of the declared generic type, or offered options of what to show -- declared, resolved, erased, ???. The more I use generics the more I find these odd situations where I can't quite figure out why the compiler is doing what it does.
In any case, thanks for considering my rather vague request.

bug.short_desc: Console view doesn't print ASCII art correctly

long_desc.thetext:
Here is the input (part from an Ant script)
<echo> foo bar </echo>
The result on the Eclipse console view is not like I expect it to be: foo bar
But if I run the script outside of Eclipse from the commandline, the result is like I expect it: foo bar
My problem with this is, that we have a Ant script which is normally executed in Eclipse and not from the commandline. Just for fun it uses a little bit of ASCII art.
This is how it should look like, when echoed from an Ant script: ~~~~~~ | | |c--OD | _) | | |-. | / `-# /A / /_|..`#.J/ ||LJ `m'
But in the Eclipse view it looks terrible like this: ~~~~~~ | | |c--OD | _) | | |-. | / `-# /A / /_|..`#.J/ ||LJ `m'
Whats the best solution to this problem, except not using ASCII art? Please no guesses, because I already tried a lot of things to solve that problem.
Granted, that there are more important problems, but I really would like to use that cool ASCII art. ;-)

Funny.
Darin, should I look into this or does it sound familiar to you?

Doesn't sound familiar to me... is the Ant script being run in the same VM as Eclipse, or a seperate VM? I think the console output is marshalled across the wire in the case of the seperate VM, and perhaps it's not being marshalled properly. Darin (S)?
I will have to look but we are likely doing a trim() that is causing problems.

I can confirm that the problem is not in the Text infrastructure but between RemoteAntBuildListener and the RemoteAntBuildLogger and it seems that the string sent from the logger is wrong. This also explains why it works if the ant script is run in the same VM.

The RemoteAntBuildLogger is doing a trim.
I can see adding a preference that by default the messages are trimmed (to retain backwards compatibility) but then if toggle off you get the pretty ascii art :-)
Trimming is just wrong. It should give the same result as when running in the same VM or outside with Ant. Why do you see a compatibility problem? The protocol seems to be internal.
Anyone who has written any tests that rely on the output would be broken if the trim is arbitrarily dropped.

Fixed the inconsistency so all builds do not trim. Happy ASCII art.
Changes to RemoteAntBuildLogger
Please verify DarinW.

bug.short_desc: launcher's doesn't allow "prepend" in bootstrap?

The launcher's "bootstrap entries" dialog appears not to allow "prepend" entries, like you can if launching natively. (-Xbootclasspath/p:<jar or directory>
This is required sometimes if, for diagnositc or testing purposes, someone needs to "replace" some class that's in the JRE they are using.
The "help" made it sound like always appended.
As I wrote this I thought maybe I could add to the "VM Arguments" field, but that appears not to work (though, I admit, I don't have the best test at the moment ... but, hey, that's never prevented me opening a bug/feature request before :)

Dave, we have no plans to use a sophisticated Classpath tab like the regular jdt launchers. the pde launchers already have too many tabs.
Plus, this is not a common scenario for testing eclipse apps to warrant such a chagne.
Please use the VM arguments to mess with your classpath prepend, etc.

Worse yet, I've discovered, the "bootstrap entries" on the PDE launcher are not even related to the -Xbootclasspath VM directive!! Boy is my face red. :)

java.awt.graphicsenv=sun.awt.Win32GraphicsEnvironment java.awt.printerjob=sun.awt.windows.WPrinterJob java.class.path=C:\Mobile\Eclipse-3.2.0\startup.jar java.class.version=49.0 java.endorsed.dirs=C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.5.0_06\lib\endorsed java.ext.dirs=C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.5.0_06\lib\ext java.home=C:\Program Files\Java\jre1.5.0_06 java.runtime.version=1.5.0_06-b05 java.specification.version=1.5 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. java.version=1.5.0_06

The problem happens in the Java text editor (the main window) when editing Java files.
The log file is not being written to on start/indenting/exiting.
Steps to reproduce: Select some lines from which at least one is empty and indent by pressing the Tab key. The empty line will have 4 spaces at the beginning.

I have a few more plugins installed. They didn't have an icon in the About dialog so I didn't notice them:
C/C++ Development Tools 3.1.0 Sony Ericsson Device Explorer 2.2.4

(In reply to comment #6) > Steps to reproduce: Select some lines from which at least one is empty and > indent by pressing the Tab key. The empty line will have 4 spaces at the > beginning.
Works as designed - Tab will only indent a line when invoked on a single line (and the Java > Editor > Typing > 'Tab indents line' preference is checked), otherwise, Tab will right shift the selection, adding an indent to empty lines.
Use Source > Correct Indentation (Ctrl+I) to indent a line range. The empty line indent is then controlled by the formatter preference mentioned in comment 2.

I can't use Ctrl+I since it sometimes reformats the source code (in some cases I deviate from my formatter settings).

bug.short_desc: If osgi.syspath changes case then initial bundles are re-installed on Windows

long_desc.thetext:
When installing the bundles specified in the osgi.bundles list the osgi.syspath is used as the base directory to search for the bundles. On Windows if the platform is launched once using an upper case directory and then again using the same directory name but lower case then all the initial bundles are reinstalled. This is because it looks like the file location has changed, but on Windows casing does not matter and the location is actually the same.
We should conanicalize sys path in Eclipse starter before using it to compare initial bundle installations.
Fix released for 3.3 M2.
Is it possible to add this to 3.2.1? We have run into this problem on 3.2 and need a patch there.

Created an attachment (id=47687) 3.2 patch
Patch for 3.2. Here is the patch to 3.2. I'm not sure this is a candidate for 3.2.1 though. The easy workaround is to not set the osgi.install.area to different cased paths for each launch of the platform.
Why do you require the ability to set them to different cased paths. Why do you not use the correct conanical path when you set the property?

Windows does not care about case in path names. Ensuring all methods of launching the platform use the same exact casing is difficult since no one looks for that on windows platforms.
We've already run into several instances where the directory casing has changed and caused problems which are very difficult to solve. Since our product gets integrated into many customer scenarios, it's unreasonable for us to require all customers to check for case.

bug.short_desc: Cycles in nested viewer

long_desc.thetext:
Should nested graphs allow cycles from a child to a parent? For example:
A has child B and B has child C, then C is related to A.
How should such cases be handled.

The view currently shows this in two ways: 1) by placing an arc to/from the focussed from/to the related node in the nested viewer (looks like an arc extending from the outside of the focus node to the related node), and by placing a proxy copy of the focus node in the appropriate client/supplier pane.

bug.short_desc: The attribute ATTR_DATA_COLLECTOR does not get written to the launch configuration despite specifying the default data collector through extension point

long_desc.thetext: We're having problems launching one of our configurations when we use the defaults. If we deselect and reselect the data collector, it launches fine. The problem seems to be that the attribute org.eclipse.hyades.trace.ui.ATTR_DATA_COLLECTOR is not written to the launch configuration when we use the defaults, but it does get written when we select/deselect the collector first.
Created an attachment (id=47787) patch

Robert,
Please test the patch. If this needs to be included in 4.2.1, then its severity needs to be increased to critical. Please change its severity and explain why it's required for your consuming product.
Thanks.

Tested patch and it fixes the problem we were having.
I've upped the severity to critical so that this is included in 4.2.1.
Why it's required: Because user's who attempt to launch a default profiling configuration for our profiling type will get an error dialog saying that a failure occurred while trying to launch our agent. The failure to launch the agent is the result of this bug.
Fix was checked into HEAD and 4.2.1 branch after PMC/PG approval
Closing.

bug.short_desc: Implement a fast fail policy for automated gui test suites

long_desc.thetext:
Provide the option of terminating the workbench running a test suite as soon as the first failure is detected:
- In many cases the user is required to wait a long time until the test suite runs to completion. - By default, the workbench should terminate when the first failure is detected. - The user will still have the option of running test suites until all test cases are completed/attempted.

Navid's intentions for this defect were different:
The user should be able to specify which test case invocations will cause the workbench to terminate when there is a failure. For example, given:
Test case #1 Test case #2 Test case #3
The user may mark test case #2 so that when it fails then the execution of the test suite is interrupted and the workbench is forced to terminate. Marking this defect as an enhancement.

I think the second idea is good, but wouldn't it be enough to notify the user each time a test fails and let them decide whether to stop or keep going manually? For example, have a status bar similar to the output generated in the Execution history which lists each test case and whether it has passed or failed (or not been started yet).
As a further enhancement, how difficult would it be to add a "pause" button so that a user running tests which require the entire desktop view could select pause if they need to use the workspace for a moment and then restart the tests afterwards to prevent another application from automatically opening during the tests and causing a failure?

I'm hesitant to display the status of the running test cases in the status bar because of the side effect that it may have on some test cases. I generally can't change the state of the workbench while executing the test suites. As an example, if you create a test case to verify the status bar output when execution history is selected, then it will fail because the status is changed by the test case playback operation. I am open for other suggestions that will help you to terminate the workbench prematurely based on the status of test cases.
As for providing a pause button during playback: it will be supported when https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=137724 is implemented.
Correcting version for this enhancement (defaulting to the current release). See http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/bugzilla.html for more information.
Correcting version for this enhancement (defaulting to the current release). See http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/bugzilla.html for more information.

Correction: Future is a valid version for this enhancement based on http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/bugzilla.html. As such, the implicit assumption is that is enhancement is of a lower priority. If incorrect, the originator should correct the version.

Updating target to future as requested by the PMC.
Enhancements are targeted to future if not in plan for the current release.
Reassigning to current component lead.

In TPTP 4.5, the AGR was moved from a Technology Preview component to an As-Is component. As-Is components are primarily provided for prior users but imply no support (for example, defects, news group, and mailing lists) or commitment to triage or resolve opened defects. For this defect to be considered, please re-open with an attached patch including code to resolve the symptom and test cases to test the fix.

bug.short_desc: [Preferences] NullPointerException in ColorsAndFontsPreferencepage when changing fonts

long_desc.thetext: This is reported against 3.1.2 on Linux-GTK (which I'm developing in), but this hasn't been corrected in HEAD. And I believe I've had this same problem under Windows and 3.2. I get many NPEs when trying to change fonts using the Fonts and Colors preference page, including just to look at the current choices. The NPEs occur because def is null in the following test from in ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.getText(j.l.Object): if (!ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.equals(def .getCategoryId(), myCategory)) { Changing this test to: if (def != null && !ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.equals(def .getCategoryId(), myCategory)) { prevents the NPE and seems to cause my expected behaviour. The trigger is that I have developed a plugin that specifies its own font definition in its plugin.xml: The text font used in the Ariadne Dossier view. I don't initialize this font to anything by default, so it should just pick up the default font (org.eclipse.jface.textFont). At least, I think that's right: I have to admit that I found the whole fonts-setting documentation to be a bit confusing.

Created an attachment (id=47648) patch to ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.java
Check that def isn't null. Not sure if this is correct, but it at least prevents the NPE.

Please post the full stack trace for the NPE as well.
PW

This problem still occurs in 3.3M3. In tracing through the code, I've discovered that the problem is ultimately attributable to a documentation error: the example describing a <fontDefinition> in the documentation for the "org.eclipse.ui.fontDefinitions" extension point sets the 'defaultsTo' attribute to the incorrect "org.eclipse.jface.textFont". This should have a lower-case `f'.
<fontDefinition id="org.eclipse.examples.userFont" label="User" defaultsTo="org.eclipse.jface.textFont"> <!-- should be textfont --> <description> The user font </description> </fontDefinition>
This is the source of the error, as I copied, pasted, and then modified this code. As a result the call to ThemeRegistry.findFont() doesn't find the default font and returns null, leading to the symptoms described previously here.
That said, a mis-configured font definition shouldn't cause walkbacks. So patch #1 to ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage.java is correct in spirit, but we might want to handle the def==null case differently and return some different text. And perhaps log a warning about the misconfiguration: this will occur on all platforms, and not just Linux-GTK.
ColorsAndFontsPreferencePage$PresentationLabelProvider.getText() has a further problem in that it assumes that the element's categoryId is be non-null. This is not a safe assumption as the example does not include a category either.

bug.short_desc: ServiceReference.isAssignableTo does not pay attention to boot delegation

long_desc.thetext:
If a package is configured to always delegate to boot first (by setting the org.osgi.framework.bootdelegation property) then the ServiceReferenceImpl.isAssignableTo method may return incorrect results when multiple bundles export that same package.
This situation is not good. If a package is always delegated to boot then it is impossible for a bundle in the framework to export that same package and provide its own version of classes already provided by the VM. If a bundle gets wired to such a package then it will still see the classes from the boot classpath. These are all well known issues when setting the org.osgi.framework.bootdelegation property. Equinox sets this property to "*" (all packages) by default for backwards compatiblity reasons.
The ServiceReferenceImpl.isAssignableTo method does not handle this case. If one bundle wires to the system bundle for a VM package javax.xml.parsers and registers an SAXParserFactory service and another bundle wires to the javax.xml.parsers package exported by a different bundle then it will not see the SAXParserFactory service. This is because the framework thinks the two bundles are loading the classes from two different sources. But they both are really getting the classes for javax.xml.parsers from the boot classpath.
We can add some simple checks to see if the package is on the boot delegation list and exported by the system bundle. If it is then ServiceReference.isAssignable should always return true because the two sources are the same (from the boot classpath).

Created an attachment (id=47689) 3.2.x patch
Patch to 3.2.x
This patch changes ServiceReferenceImpl to check to see if the package is a boot delegation package. If it is and the system bundle exports that package from the VM execution environment then "true" is returned because every bundle is using that package from the VM.

This patch has been released to HEAD for 3.3 M2. Jeff, can we consider this fix for 3.2.1? If this fix is not released we run the risk of the equinox.registry getting wired to another javax.xml.parsers package exported by another bundle in the system. This ultimately will cause it to not be able to aquire the XML parser and results in an empty extension registry.
Fix released to 3.2.1 stream.

bug.short_desc: libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so missing from linux-gtk-ppc Eclipse R3.2

long_desc.thetext:
I ran the Eclipse automated tests today and among other failures, I'm seeing 147 failures in org.eclipse.swt.junit (target = swt). All of these 147 failures appear to be because libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so is missing from org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.ppc-3.2.0.v3232.jar. Said shared object is present in the R3.2 for linux-gtk-x86.
In CVS, there is a libswt-mozilla17-profile-gtk-3304.so starting in version 3304, but not earlier. I ran the automated tests on Eclipse 3.2 RC3..RC7 and didn't see these problems. So I'm not certain these tests really ought to be failing if the library is not present. Perhaps these are new regression tests. I don't know.
Here's the error message I'm seeing in the log:
No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: Can't find library swt-mozilla-gtk-3232 (libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so) in sun.boot.library.path or java.library.path sun.boot.library.path=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1_4_2-ibm-1.4.2.s4/jre/bin java.library.path=/usr/lib/jvm/java-1_4_2-ibm-1.4.2.s4/jre/bin:/usr/lib/jvm/java-1_4_2-ibm-1.4.2.s4/jre/bin/classic:/usr/lib/jvm/java-1_4_2-ibm-1.4.2.s4/jre/bin:/usr/lib:/usr/openwin/lib:/usr/dt/lib:/opt/SUNWmotif/lib:/usr/xc/r5/lib:/usr/ccs/lib:/usr/ucblib:/home/corey/lib:/usr/lib)

Browser support was just added on linux-ppc recently (see bug 151330). The automated Browser tests assume that a Browser is available, so these tests all should have consistently failed on linux-ppc up until ~ last week.
I just ran the tests on ppc using the latest swt (the one that will be in 3.3M1 later today), and all tests passed, including the Browser ones, with the AllGtkTests test suite; I just had to set its -Djava.library.path to point at the org.eclipse.swt.gtk.linux.ppc fragment so that our libraries would be found.
I think the only problem here is the missing Browser support on ppc in eclipse 3.2. I'm not sure if this is something that can be added to the 3.2.1 stream, because platforms without browser support are not new or isolated to ppc. SN?
Is the browser on PPC stable? It *should* be, however, if it isn't for some reason, we will destabilize the 3.2.x stream. Your call ...
I've been using Firefox 1.5.0.4 on a PowerPC machine running SLES 10 and it works fine. In fact, I'm using it now to add this comment I'm writing.

On further thought, I don't think that putting this into 3.2.1 is the thing to do. The platform does not get broad test coverage, and the fix has only been in the 3.3 stream for a short time. Given the Browser's history of working on some machines and not on others, it's best to not risk destabilizing 3.2.1 since platforms without Browser support are handled well by eclipse.

I see that the state is set to WONTFIX. Does that imply that it won't be fixed in 3.3 either?
If not, I think this bug should be reset to open.
This is fixed in the 3.3 stream. It was fixed slightly before this report was logged, so I took this report to refer specifically to the library being added to 3.2.1.

bug.short_desc: DirectoryDialog's setFilterPath() has no effect

long_desc.thetext:
The DirectoryDialog's setFilterPath() has no effect on the Mac (Eclipse 3.1.1 and 3.2). Instead of showing the specified directory, the dialog presents the previously chosen directory.
An SWT newsgroup poster reported the same situation on Linux. However, things seem fine on Windows.
Steve Northover replied on the newsgroup saying that it looked like the method was never implemented on the Mac.
The same appears to be the case for FileDialog.

bug.short_desc: [adopter breakage scan] Interface implementors omitted in adopter scans?

long_desc.thetext:
As part of a bug fix, I was looking at adding a new method to the internal interface org.eclipse.jst.server.core.IJavaRuntime. The new method would have been "boolean isUsingDefaultJRE()".
I added the method and ran an API scan, and it passed with no problems. I then looked in the HTML version of the API reports and noticed that the interface is being used. I checked with one of the adopter teams (conan@ca.ibm.com). They have been implementing IJavaRuntime, and adding the new method would break them.
Maybe this is an edge case, but it would be nice to know if changing an interface will break an adopter just like any other change would. If we don't want to get into this much detail or it would require additional information from adopters, then we should make all changes to interfaces used by adopters as API breaks.

bug.short_desc: eclipse 3.3 stream builds broken on Solaris GTK

long_desc.thetext:
The Eclipse SDK in recent 3.3 stream builds on Solaris GTK is broken. The SWT team has determined that the Converter class in the org.eclipse.swt.gtk.solaris.sparc fragment appears to be corrupt. It is ~8 bytes smaller than that produced for eclipse 3.2 and the Converter class has not changed since 3.2. The compiler does not appear to be a factor as the class file was compiled using the same compiler and args as that used to produce eclipse 3.2.
The jar conditioning using pack200 is currently suspect since a test build without packing the jars fixed the problem.
pack200 has been disabled in the builds for the time being until this can be further investigated.

This is a bug in pack200, likely this one: http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=6401454
Bug is fixed in Java 6. Workaround is to use an effort level of 4 (default is 5) when running pack 200 on this jar (-E4).
Using -E4 can be accomplished by adding a pack.properties file to the zip on which the jarprocessor is run. Although we will need some Ant to make sure we get the jar name correct because of changing version numbers. (Or, more easily by bug 146066 if/when that fix is released.)
Is pack.properties a java properties file and if yes, what is the associated property name for the "-E4: value?

Yes, it is a java properties file. The property would be: org.eclipse.swt.gtk.solaris.sparc_3.2.0.v3305a.jar.pack.args = -E4 Note the need to have the version correct in the file name.
If you are using a version of update.core that contains the patch from bug 146066, then you can create a META-INF/eclipse.inf file in the swt fragment. This is also a java.properties file, and here the property would be pack200.args = -E4
Adding Grant to cc. to create the eclipse.inf file.
fixed > 0815 in the solaris-gtk fragments for sparc and x86 by adding the prescribed META-INF/eclipse.inf file to each.

Which class? Converter? I don't see that in the windows version of the fragment. Is there a place I can easily get a not-packed version of the swt fragment for windows?
I'm asking because I'm trying to determine if this "fragment problem" could possibly account for an odd, bad bug we are seeing using GEF with M1 (in our WTP project). See bug 155283.

We were not aware of any problems in the win32 fragment. The Converter class was not the only corrupted class in the gtk fragment, several others in the same package were corrupt. I'm not sure whether all the classes were corrupt or just some of them.
Pack200 was turned off while we came up with a workaround, so there should exist a build or two with unpacked fragments, but I'm not sure which builds those would be. Sonia or Kim may know better.

Created an attachment (id=49034) spread sheet of 32, 33M1, 33Ix class sizes from fragments
Just thought I'd dump this data here. In case anyone ever wants to look.
I tried to see if class files "looked" corrupt, but, I couldn't really tell anything. Perhaps someone from swt team could.

David, I think that if bug 155283 was caused by the pack problem then your app would crash when trying to load the corrupted class. So I don't think it's the same thing.
That being said, since you indicate that bug 155283 is now working for you with a recent integration build, it seems like no more investigation is needed here (maybe swt introduced a regression in M1 and has fixed it since?).

bug.short_desc: Failing Polymorphism mechanism in XPAND

long_desc.thetext:
Having (EMF) model classes separated in separate model packages (see test.test2.CAA) the polymorphism mechanism of XPAND fails.
test.A test.BA -> (inherits from) test.A test.Package (Top Model Component) |_ items (Reference on a Set of type test.A)
test.CA -> test.A test.test2.CAA -> test.CA
For Instances of Type A and BA the correct XPAND templates are called. When resolving instances of type CAA a template for the target type 'Object' is required (the content type of the model set though would be A, the correct type CAA). Additionally an exception is logged to the console (provided at the end of this bug entry).
This is a blocker since it prevents separating models into packages and using specialization/generalization.
My environment is: - Eclipse 3.2.0 - M20060629-1905 - EMF 2.2.0 200606272057 - oaW 4.1, RC2. - JDK 1.5.0_06 (- SuSE Linux 10.0)
The exception thrown was:
2509 ERROR WorkflowRunner - No Definition 'Polymorphism for Object' found!:in Root.xpt on line 6 'EXPAND Polymorphism FOREACH items' org.openarchitectureware.expression.EvaluationException: No Definition 'Polymorphism for Object' found!:in Root.xpt on line 6 'EXPAND Polymorphism FOREACH items' at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.ast.ExpandStatement.invokeDefinition(ExpandStatement.java:166) at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.ast.ExpandStatement.evaluateInternal(ExpandStatement.java:144) at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.ast.Statement.evaluate(Statement.java:27) at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.ast.AbstractDefinition.evaluate(AbstractDefinition.java:93) at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.ast.ExpandStatement.invokeDefinition(ExpandStatement.java:181) at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.ast.ExpandStatement.evaluateInternal(ExpandStatement.java:157) at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.ast.Statement.evaluate(Statement.java:27) at org.openarchitectureware.xpand2.Generator.invokeInternal(Generator.java:169) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.lib.AbstractWorkflowComponent2.invoke(AbstractWorkflowComponent2.java:38) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.container.CompositeComponent.internalInvoke(CompositeComponent.java:74) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.container.CompositeComponent.invoke(CompositeComponent.java:64) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.container.CompositeComponent.internalInvoke(CompositeComponent.java:74) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.container.CompositeComponent.invoke(CompositeComponent.java:64) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.WorkflowRunner.executeWorkflow(WorkflowRunner.java:222) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.WorkflowRunner.run(WorkflowRunner.java:162) at org.openarchitectureware.workflow.WorkflowRunner.main(WorkflowRunner.java:115)

bug.short_desc: Birt Web Viewer incorrectly exports Japanese characters

long_desc.thetext:
Tested on a Windows 2000 Server machine with US English locale setting, BIRT build 2006-08-08: (1) Save the attached file jp_utf8.txt to a local directory (2) Open the attached report design jp_export.rptdesign in BIRT designer (3) Edit the data source definition so that its "Select Folder" box is filled with the correct directory where you have saved the file in step (1). (4) Preview the report in Web Viewer. You will see correct Japanese text being shown. (5) Export all columns and save the resulting csv file (do not open it in Excel) (6) Rename the export file exportdata.csv to exportdata.txt. Now open the txt file in a browser (I tested with both Firefox 1.5 and IE6). The text file shows garbage characters in place of Japanese characters. It does not help if you change the character encoding in the browser setting: neither UTF-8, Japan shift-JIS, or other Japanese encoding works. The Japanese characters are lost.
Expected behavior: For universal language support, Export Data should always export in UTF-8 encoding.
Created an attachment (id=47671) jp_utf8.txt
Created an attachment (id=47672) jp_export.rptdesign
*** Bug 153294 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

(In reply to comment #0) Let me explain what I understood from your comments. 1) BIRT need to export data in UTF-8 encoding only to support universal language. That is not happening now. 2) You are working on this bug.
Please correct me if I am wrong.
The exported data is encoded in UTF-8. So, when you open the txt file and set the browser encoding to UFT-8, it should be displayed correctly.

(In reply to comment #5) Shall I need to update the BIRT 2.1 installation to get this fix ?? I mean to say that you resolved this bug from your end bug but how can I implement your fix to my BIRT 2.1 platform ??
You will see this fix in BIRT night build 2006-08-11 and later. Or wait for the 2.1.1 release due out in late Sept.

By using the command line:
eclipse -vm and then specify a JDK higher than 1.4.2
Thanks.

bug.short_desc: Using default JRE doesn't set classpath correctly

long_desc.thetext:
According to Scott Peddle there is a defect headed my way for this. I have the fix ready, so I'm opening this bug to check the code in and will dup the real bug when it reaches me.
When you pick to use the default JRE when using Tomcat or the J2EE runtime library, it still uses the full JRE classpath container. This makes the user's project not compatible between workspaces if they do not have the same name for the default JRE. I'm putting in two fixes - one to the facet runtime bridge to use the default JRE, and one in Tomcat & J2EE runtime library to use the workspace default JRE by default, instead of the specific JRE that it represents.
Code dropped to HEAD and released to 1.5.1 and 2.0 streams.
Closing.
This is part of a "mass update" where bugs showing "fixed" between 7/1/2006 and 9/27/2006 are assumed fixed in WTP 1.5.1. feel free to change the target milestone if you know a more accurate setting.

bug.short_desc: Parse method in ReportParamterConverter convert float type to double type

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Parse method in ReportParamterConverter convert float type to double type
Steps to reproduce: 1. use parse() to convert a string to float type String var1="3.5"; converter.parse( float1,IScalarParameterDefn.TYPE_FLOAT );
Expected result: parse method returns a Float instance
Actual result: returned a Double instance despite that I　defined TYPE_FLOAT

the TYPE_FLOAT means it is a float number, which can be either the double or float.
Add a javadoc to the API please.
Fixed.
Related java doc is added before parse method. close it.

bug.short_desc: Creating a deep directory structure fails silently

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to reproduce: create a simple project for i=1 to (path is at least 250+ characters) create a inside the last created dir with a long name (50 chars) refresh the project the last created folder "disappears" from the navigator try do do anything of the created directory, and you get a popup "resource <blabla> is out of sync with the file system"
under the windows explorer, rename the first few root folder as "a" (ie a very short name) repeat going down in the folder hierarchy four or five times refesh the project again the folders that were created reappear
So there is some weird interactions between the limitation of the Windows Api where there is some limitation ~250 chars when a non UTF api is used (if I recall) (for instance Windows Explorer is a good exmaple of that stupid limitation), and the Java capabilities (the core.filesystem uses Java mkdirs to create directories) which have no such limitations but instead use the full NTFS capabilities.
IMHO, there should be either : - some way for a user not to get in that mess - some way to handle that gracefully

Note that there are known JDK issues at play there... http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4403166
and a related albeit different bugs here: bug 69620 bug 30995
and the whole explanantion here: http://msdn.microsoft.com/library/default.asp?url=/library/en-us/fileio/fs/naming_a_file.asp
I would assume that core.filesystem's local file implementation could have the opportunity to fix that

bug.short_desc: [Regression]Label text won't show up when the text key is not found

long_desc.thetext:
Steps to reproduce: 1.Add a label, set text to "aaa" 2.Add a resource file "a" to the report, add a text key "k1" which is not in the a.properties to the label 3.Preview in Web Viewer
Expected result: Label display "aaa" when the text key is not found
Actual result: Nothing in preview
DocumentUtil doesn't write out the lable correctly.
Fixed.
Verified on build 20060821

Note: If I revert to 1.4.1.20060728033634 then I dont get this error.
I do this via Help -> Software Updates -> Manage Configuration -> Replace With Another Version.
Passing over to compiler

suspect this is a pipeline bug - you can try deactivating the pipeline to see if it helps, set the option:
-Xset:pipelineCompilation=false
in your project properties. Pipelining compilation uses far less memory but is a brand new feature and thus has a few bugs to iron out.
i found a different crash whilst investigating - fixing that first.

I can confirm that when I set this:
-Xset:pipelineCompilation=false
in the AspectJ Compiler Non-standard compiler options the problem does NOT appear.

The problem appears to be due to the use of ITDs. The cast that blows up is casting something it believes is a BcelTypeMunger. Really the only other possibility for the object is an EclipseTypeMunger - but at this stage of weaving all the Eclipse ones ought to have been transformed into Bcel ones. I don't want the fix to be a guard for checking it is an instanceof EclipseTypeMunger and skipping it in that case as we'll get peculiar results in some situations - we really need to get to the bottom of why this type munger hasn't been transformed.
My current thought is that we have exited stage one of the pipeline too early - at exit of stage one, all aspects must have been compiled and it is possible the code that identifies the aspects and sorts the list of files to process is misbehaving.
Can you tell me - how are your aspects defined? Are they code style/annotation style? Are all aspects declared as top level types or do you have some member type aspects? How many aspects do you have?

Downgraded seriousness - no reply for a month - can't progress this bug without a bit more info. I presume you are continuing with the workaround flag? please add a comment if you find a few moments to help me work on it.

> Can you tell me - how are your aspects defined? Are they code style/annotation > style? Are all aspects declared as top level types or do you have some member > type aspects? How many aspects do you have?
I have 3 aspects in total, all small. The first simply makes any class that matches a class level annotation implement a particular interface:
declare parents: (@KeyValue *) implements IKeyValueCoding, KvcMixinImpl; public Object KvcMixinImpl.getValueForKey( String key ) { .... }
etc. The next does the same, but also intercepts some variable setting:
after( IKeyValueObserving target ): set( !@KvoManual java.util.List ( @KeyValue * ).* ) && target( target )
pointcut setter() : set( !@KvoManual * (@KeyValue *).* ) && @within(KeyValue) && !withincode( new(..) );
void around( Object input, IKeyValueObserving target ): setter() && args(input) && target(target)
The last one does the same as the first, but for a different interface. I can post the entire aspect code here if thats appropriate? (It's open source at SourceForge).
I have been using the workaround, and don't encounter the problem anymore. I haven't tried taking it off recently.
If you could zip up the source and send it to me google ID, I can take a look at it...

I get pretty much the same bug, I'll try to provide the relevant information. Hopefully it'll be enough to reproduce it.
I also confirm that -Xset:pipelineCompilation=false fixes the issue.
Running on Windows XP Professional.
Sun JDK java version "1.5.0_10" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_10-b03) Java HotSpot(TM) Client VM (build 1.5.0_10-b03, mixed mode, sharing)

The exact trace as shown in Eclipse: java.lang.ClassCastException at org.aspectj.weaver.patterns.SignaturePattern.matchesAnnotations(SignaturePattern.java:477) at org.aspectj.weaver.patterns.SignaturePattern.matchesExactly(SignaturePattern.java:332) at org.aspectj.weaver.patterns.SignaturePattern.matches(SignaturePattern.java:289) at org.aspectj.weaver.patterns.KindedPointcut.matchInternal(KindedPointcut.java:106) at org.aspectj.weaver.patterns.Pointcut.match(Pointcut.java ... when batch building BuildConfig[C:\Lang\eclipse-3.2.1\workspace\.metadata\.plugins\org.eclipse.ajdt.core\Java Beans Aspect.generated.lst] #Files=16

bug.short_desc: Problam with embeded browser control on Linux x86_64 GTK2+

long_desc.thetext:
Eclipse 3.2 for OS_ARCH=x86_64 and GTK2+ OS = Ubuntu 6.06 Desktop (64-bit)
java version "1.5.0_07" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.5.0_07-b03) Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 1.5.0_07-b03, mixed mode)
Problem:
SWT web browser component is crashing with UnsatisfiedLinkError as mentioned in steps to reproduce section below. In my application I have used swt browser components very widely, also it is used in welcome page as well. Because of this one of product is crashing at launch time and other product dont show any details of view in which browser component is embedded. Things are working fine on other Linux platforms but it is failing on Linux x86_64.
Steps to reproduce:
In Eclipse 1) Select Windows->Show View->Other to open Show View dialog 2) Select General->Internal Web Browser
In internal web browser view it shows message "Embedded browser not available". On Clicking "Details" button it shows following exception:
No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: no swt-mozilla-gtk-3232 in java.library.path) org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: no swt-mozilla-gtk-3232 in java.library.path) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3400) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3297) at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.<init>(Browser.java:166) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.browser.BrowserViewer.<init>(BrowserViewer.java:224) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.browser.WebBrowserView.createPartControl(WebBrowserView.java:48) : Caused by: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: no swt-mozilla-gtk-3232 in java.library.path at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(ClassLoader.java:1682) at java.lang.Runtime.loadLibrary0(Runtime.java:822) at java.lang.System.loadLibrary(System.java:992) at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Library.loadLibrary(Library.java:123) at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.<init>(Browser.java:151) ... 37 more
So I looked for libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so file in configuration folder but I could not found it. Downloaded swt packs of standalone swt application for linux(32-bit) and Linux(64-bit). Observed that libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so file does not exists in Linux(64-bit) zip but present in Linux(32-bit) zip. Coppied 32-bit libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so fole to "/home/exceed/IDEs/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/79/1/.cp/" folder where I found other relavent .so files. Restarted eclipse and this time following exception shown in Browser View.
No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /home/exceed/IDEs/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/79/1/.cp/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so: /home/exceed/IDEs/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/79/1/.cp/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory) org.eclipse.swt.SWTError: No more handles (java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /home/exceed/IDEs/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/79/1/.cp/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so: /home/exceed/IDEs/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/79/1/.cp/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3400) at org.eclipse.swt.SWT.error(SWT.java:3297) at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.<init>(Browser.java:166) at org.eclipse.ui.internal.browser.BrowserViewer.<init>(BrowserViewer.java:224) : Caused by: java.lang.UnsatisfiedLinkError: /home/exceed/IDEs/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/79/1/.cp/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so: /home/exceed/IDEs/eclipse/configuration/org.eclipse.osgi/bundles/79/1/.cp/libswt-mozilla-gtk-3232.so: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory at java.lang.ClassLoader$NativeLibrary.load(Native Method) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary0(ClassLoader.java:1751) at java.lang.ClassLoader.loadLibrary(ClassLoader.java:1676) at java.lang.Runtime.loadLibrary0(Runtime.java:822) at java.lang.System.loadLibrary(System.java:992) at org.eclipse.swt.internal.Library.loadLibrary(Library.java:123) at org.eclipse.swt.browser.Browser.<init>(Browser.java:151) ... 42 more
*** Bug 153424 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

I notice that Ubuntu 6.06 is quite new. Does it have a /usr/lib/xulrunner or /usr/lib/xul-runner-xxxx directory by any chance? And if so, do your apps run any better if you first set your MOZILLA_FIVE_HOME environment variable to this directory and add it to your LD_LIBRARY_PATH?
that second path should have been /usr/lib/xulrunner-xxxx not /usr/lib/xul-runner-xxxx

bug.short_desc: [DND] Drag and drop of Treeview doesn't work in BIRT on Macintosh
callisto and datatools update sites slightly out of sync

There is a similar effect if I "install" from Callisto, or install from the datatools update site directly.
We should be sure these "stay in synch".
As they are "brought" into synch, the feature(s) that include org.eclipse.datatools.connectivity.oda.flatfile should be "bumped up" to be sure those that have old one installed will get new one "automatically" (e.g. by using "search for updates to currently installed featues).

updated DTP feature defs and corresponding info on Callisto build site.
verified and closing

bug.short_desc: [Context Sensitive] Wrong help content for Edit data set parameter binding dialog

long_desc.thetext:
Description: The help content for Edit data set parameter binding dialog isn't correct.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Create a datasource and a dataset, add a dataset parameter in the dataset 2. Create a dynamic image, bind it with the dataset, open Dataset Parameter Binding dialog, the dataset parameter will show up, set focus on it, click Edit button, Edit data set parameter binding dialog will pop up 3. Press help button or F1 key
Expected result: Correct context help will show up
Actual result: The context help is "Each workbench window contains one or more perspectives, which are made up of various views and editors."
What is the help context id for this dialog?

I find there's no Id for this dialog, maybe the code owner forgot to add it.
The dialog mentioned in the bug is DataColumnBindingDialog, whose Id is DataColumnBindingDialog_ID. Except this one, there's anther dialog DataColumnBindingDialog, whose Id is DataItemBindingDialog_ID.
I've added the ids for the two dialogs.
Jane, If you have some questions about the two dialogs, please contact Chao Chen(cchen@actuate.com),who wrote the dialogs.Now, I've added him to CC list.
I've check in the two Ids in main and 2.1.1 branch. Thank you.
Chao, would you please tell Jane the steps to open the dialog DataItemBindingDialog and the use of the two dialogs ?

1,If add or edit a DataItem at the designer editor,then use the DataItemBindingDialog.
DataItemBindingDialog is used to set the data item 's data binding.
2,Open the Property Editor and select the binding tab,there has two buttons: add and edit...,it use DataColumnBindingDialog. 3,At the designer editor,select a dataitem,click right mouse button,select "Change data column",popup the select data column dialog,there has two buttons: add and edit...,it use DataColumnBindingDialog.
DataColumnBindingDialog is used to binding a column to the designer element.
Thanks for the IDs and the information on how to reach these new dialogs. I have added the context-sensitive help to both development and 2.1.1 branches.
Verified in daily build 20060904. The help content for "Edit Data Binding" dialog is correct now, but not fixed for "Edit data set parameter binding" dialog.

The help Id is DataSetParameterBindingInputDialog_ID, I'll check it in later. Jane, This dialog is added by Yueqian(ywang@actuate.com), I've added it to the CC list, if you have some problems about the help contents, you can ask him for help, thanks.
I've checked in the Id, including head and 2.1.1 branch.

I have added context-sensitive help for these dialogs in both dev and 2.1.1 branches, but it's not a very clean solution. In a future release, it would be better to have separate IDs for these very different dialogs.
Verified in daily build 20060905. Fixed.

bug.short_desc: Viewer needs to follow the change for "required" parameter

long_desc.thetext: Currently when user created Parameter, there is no "required" field. When user run repot design, there is "required" field. We should have a required field to avoid confusion for user who design the report and who run report. UI will do some changes.Viewer nneds tofollow this change.
Do UI and model already have this setting for parameter? is "allow null" == "required" or "allow blank"==required?
Parameter deifnition already has a filed to indicate its required. Its called 'Allow blank'.
true means "allow null" or "required" then?

That's the bug GUI file to viewer. What's the reason to assign back? By comments from Wenfeng, "let' not change the designer and model, only at the viewer parameter level to present to user if a parameter is required. (use * to indicated instead of "not allow null" nor "required")."
Viwer current behavior to indicate whether a parameter is required is correct. If the parameter is not allow null and no default value, then the parameter is required. So, nothing to change.

bug.short_desc: Identification of Widgets

long_desc.thetext: It would be a big big benefit, if there would be a read/writeable string property "name" or "identifier" to identify Widgets. Since many applications usees setData() and getData() for their own purposes this can not be used.

You could use setData(String key, Object value) for that.
Ben
See also bug 109035.

Marking as a duplicate of bug 109035. Using setData(String key, Object value) should be an adequate way of accomplishing this; if it's not for your context then you should add a comment to bug 109035.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 109035 ***
