bug.short_desc: Invalid thread access in Snippet133

long_desc.thetext: FH to investigate. Note that I did not see this error when I tried running the snippet on my win2000.

thanks, fixed in head > 20060814
display.syncExec(printingThread); will cause the printer job to run in the UI thread, which can cause the UI to freeze. the fix is to cache all data before starting the print job.

bug.short_desc: [javadoc] JDT Core should warn if the @value tag is not used correctly

long_desc.thetext:
I20060810-0010.
JDT Core should warn if the @value tag is not used correctly, e.g. if in 1.4 the tag is used anywhere else than a constant. Otherwise developers see no Javadoc problem inside Eclipse but then get burned by the 'javadoc' tool with: warning - Inline tag {@value} should only be used with a constant field.
See also bug 144866 which should be revisited.
Also note that the @value tag usage changed with 5.0: http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.5.0/docs/tooldocs/solaris/javadoc.html#@value
Created an attachment (id=54078) Proposed patch
Released for 3.3 M4 in HEAD stream.
Verified for 3.3M4 with I20061212-0010.

bug.short_desc: huge amount of stale data held by ContentDescribers

long_desc.thetext:
If we create IStructuredModel by calling ModelManagerImpl.getModelForRead(String id, InputStream inputStream, URIResolver resolver) and release the model by calling releaseFromRead(), the whole model leaks.
Here is the reference chain. ------------------------------------------------------------------ org.eclipse.wst.html.core.internal.document.DocumentStyleImpl (#005f4f03) document of org.eclipse.wst.html.core.internal.document.DOMStyleModelImpl (#003140da) fRequester of org.eclipse.wst.xml.core.internal.parser.XMLStructuredDocumentReParser (#01ae6a59) fReParser of org.eclipse.wst.sse.core.internal.text.JobSafeStructuredDocument (#01f49052) fDocument of org.eclipse.wst.sse.core.internal.document.DocumentReader (#014059ba) in of org.eclipse.core.internal.content.LazyReader (#018dd46a) fReader of org.eclipse.wst.html.core.internal.contenttype.HTMLResourceEncodingDetector (#017c2c1f) resourceCharsetDetector of org.eclipse.wst.html.core.internal.contenttype.ContentDescriberForHTML (#00bfe887) describer of org.eclipse.core.internal.content.ContentType (#013b2ed8) value of java.util.HashMap$Entry (#00d8bad4) [62] of java.util.HashMap$Entry[128] (#00111660) table of java.util.HashMap (#00ec9a80) contentTypes of org.eclipse.core.internal.content.ContentTypeCatalog (#00807d14) catalog of org.eclipse.core.internal.content.ContentTypeManager (#0193ca0d) instance of org.eclipse.core.internal.content.ContentTypeManager (#00c914b6) ------------------------------------------------------------------
The IDocument field in the DocumentReader class is now nulled on close(). Fixed.
Similar leak still exists.

Created an attachment (id=49820) test case
IStructuredModel.save() seems to have similar leak. I have created a test case.

Created an attachment (id=49821) temporary fix
I have also created a temporary fix. I know it is not appropriate for the permanent fix but I hope it will help you understand what is the problem.
I am changing the severity to major because this is a whole model leak. This should be fixed in 3.2.1.

Just to be sure we are seeing this issue the same, this is not a leak in the traditional sense of the word, right? Its just a large piece of stale data that sticks around until the next time the ContentDescriber is used? Right? Nothing's "growing"?

First of all, I would like to thank you very much for investigating this issue at the very last phase of development.
Yes. I believe we are looking at the same issue. What I am seeing is that one model will not be released until the next time ContentDescriber is used. ContentDescriber holds one model forever. This is not a growing leak but the stale model holds its adapters and one of the adapters holds our editor.

Created an attachment (id=50552) proposed fix
Oh, thank you Saitoh-san ... you analysis and partial patches help make the investigation much easier!
I think for ContentDescribers, the best pattern to use to fix this sort of problem is to make sure that ContentDescribers never have any "state" or instance data, since one instance of ContentDescriber is always held in memory by the ContentDescriberCatalog, it effectively becomes a "root" object, never being garbaged collected.
The attached patch follows that pattern and fixes the problem. (The original fix, of nulling out document when a DocumentReader is closed is still the correct thing to do, so no need to revert that!).
The fix does cause an extra, short lived object to be constructed, but I used the OpenNavigatorFolderTest.java to verify (in my workspace) that this does not increase the time to process several thousand files, so, should be fine.

Created an attachment (id=50553) improved JUnit test for memory use
This is the original attached test case, but moved to our "performance test" packages, so its easier to see memory use before and after the fix applied. I also added a big file (500K) so the stale data would show up easier, without using a heap analysis.

I've changed the title to be more descriptive of root problem, now that its been investigated.
I would like to put this in 1.5.1. While not a growing leak, it can, as described, end up causing a huge amount of data to stay in memory needlessly. Not only does this "choke up" the system for end-users! it also acts as "noise" in the system so it makes finding other performanace problems and memory leaks much harder to find.
The correctness is easy to verify, and I regression tested performance implications by using the JUnit tests named in previous comments. We already use this "no state" pattern for JSP and CSS ContentDescriber. Not sure how we missed HTML, but we also "missed" DTD, so I propose to fix that too.
So, here's my +1

I've released the code for build, on my own recognizance.
If any pmc members object, I will revert the code until the issue is settled.
Thank you very much. I confirmed the fix solved our original problem in my developement environment.
+1 for WTP 1.5.1
Closing as fixed since WTP 1.5.1. Please reopen if closed in error.
